Now is an incredible time to be working with AI and ML.

Now is an incredible time to be working with AI and ML. 

The rapid pace of innovation has created huge opportunities for those who are either technical or entrepreneurial or both (what I call a data entrepreneur). 

These opportunities boil down to one thing: use AI to improve existing business processes 📈 

While this can take many forms, here are three general directions I see.

1️⃣ Use AI to improve other people’s businesses (i.e. consulting) 
2️⃣ Use AI to improve your business 
3️⃣ Build an AI product that can improve many businesses 

👉 The “best” path is largely dependent on your current knowledge, which I like to partition along the axes of “Technical Knowledge” and “Domain Knowledge”. 

Which quadrant do you consider yourself in? 👇

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 4/5)

ML Foundations for AI Engineers (part 4/5)

What is Deep Learning?

Although the traditional ML techniques can perform a wide range of tasks, picking the right “features” (i.e. inputs) for these models requires domain expertise.

Deep Learning (DL), on the other hand, doesn’t have the same requirement.

DL involves training neural nets that learn optimal features for an arbitrary task.

💡 The key intuition of deep learning is that layers in a neural net build upon previous ones to derive increasingly complex (and helpful) features for performing the given task.

This means we can trade the need for domain expertise for more data when developing a model 🧠 → 💿


Stay tuned for tomorrow’s post, where I’ll discuss how reinforcement learning works...

My (realistic) entrepreneur journey (so far)…

My (realistic) entrepreneur journey (so far)…

Entrepreneurship tends to be glamorized and mysticized by popular culture, but this couldn’t be further from the truth.

Here’s my timeline.

2019: I started learning Python and doing applied ML research
2020: I posted my 1st technical YouTube video and blog post
2021: I got my first freelance data science gig
2022: I got my first corporate data science role
2023: I quit my job to do content and freelance full-time
2024: I burned through savings and made several pivots
2025: I finally found an offer that can match my full-time income

It took me 5 years from posting my first YouTube video to turn that into a sustainable business.

The moral of the story is that you're not going to find a winning lottery ticket overnight, but if you’re willing to put in the work for 5 years, then you might.

So, if this is a path you see for yourself, start now... in whatever small way you can.

Matías 4X'ed his Upwork leads by rewriting his profile to be **client-focused**

Matías 4X'ed his Upwork leads by rewriting his profile to be **client-focused**

This inspired me to build an LLM system to optimize my profile too...

It's been 3 years since I last used Upwork.

Looking back at my profile, it's amazing that anyone ever hired me, because my profile is so bad 😅

That's why I recently built an AI copywriter to rewrite my profile using the "Evaluator-Optimizer" agent design pattern.

Here's how it works:

1. Input profile
2. Profile is evaluated via a rule-based test suite
3. If tests are passed, break out of the loop
4. Test results are translated into a prompt to rewrite profile
5. Profile is rewritten
6. Repeat from Step 2

4 Stats Concepts That Rewired My Brain 🧠

4 Stats Concepts That Rewired My Brain 🧠 

If you want to understand how our (messy) world works, then you need to think statistically.

Here are the ideas that have helped me think more clearly…

1) Distributions

While it’s easy to wrap our heads around summary stats like mean, median, variance, etc., they don’t always tell the whole story.

Behind every summary stat is a whole distribution of numbers. Picturing this every time I see a summary stat helped me have a better understanding of reality.

2) Conditional Probabilities

Once I imagine a distribution in my head, it’s important to understand how this distribution will change in light of new evidence.

For example, the probability a business survives 4 more years is 54%, however, if the business has been around for a year, this probability jumps to 62%

3) Expectation Values

Probabilities help us make decisions under uncertainty, but they are not the only thing that matters. You also need to consider potential upside and downside.

For example, even if a new business venture has a 10% chance of success, if success means $10M in profit, it still makes sense to pursue it.

4) Fat Tails

While the majority of stats we learn in school center around the normal distribution (i.e., bell curve), many things follow a different distribution—a Pareto (i.e., 80-20 rule).

Normal distributions focus on the typical. However, it is often the atypical, rare event that makes an impact e.g. 1% of customers can make up 50% of sales!


What are some stats concepts that shaped your thinking?

--

I recently read the original GPT paper

I recently read the original GPT paper

For those who don’t know, GPT (i.e. Generative Pre-trained Transformer) is the v1 of the model that underlies ChatGPT 🤖💬 

It works via a 2 step process 

👉 Step 1: train a base model (i.e. a transformer) to do word prediction on a large corpus of unlabeled text (i.e. billions of tokens) 

👉 Step 2: fine-tune the base model for specific tasks via (thousands) labeled examples 

It’s amazing how this simple process (on a large enough scale) can generate the responses that come out of ChatGPT 

This leaves me to wonder what else this paradigm can be used for 🤔

*** 

What do you think? What applications of this approach are you excited about?

Although text and images may look very different to us, to a neural network, these are represented via the same mathematical object, i.e., a vector.

Although text and images may look very different to us, to a neural network, these are represented via the same mathematical object, i.e., a vector.

Therefore, we can image vector spaces where text and images look similar, given they represent the same underlying information.

This is the key idea behind multimodal embeddings.

2025 is said to be “the year of AI agents”

2025 is said to be “the year of AI agents”

However, no one seems to agree on a single definition for these systems.

Here’s my explanation of AI agents (without the hype)…

Since people can’t agree on a single definition of an AI agent, most practitioners talk about agentic systems instead.

In other words, thinking about agents on a spectrum of agency, ranging from no agency (e.g. rule-based system) to human-level agency.

Here are some examples of that.

Level 1: LLM + Tools 🤖🪛 

Giving LLMs access to tools like a code interpreter, web search, or retrieval system allows them to gather information from the real world and perform actions in it.

Level 2: LLM Workflows 🤖 ➡️ 🤖🪛 

While giving an LLM tools makes it practical, it is still limited because it is forced to perform tasks in a one-shot fashion.

We can overcome this by orchestrating several software components (code or LLM) to accomplish complex tasks.

Level 3: LLM in a Loop 🤖🔄 

Some tasks may not be predictable enough to solve with a pre-defined workflow (even with LLMs).

This is where looping LLM calls can be powerful. This basic flow goes like this.

Generate response from LLM → Evaluate response → if task is complete stop; else add feedback to context and call LLM

Are you building any agents in 2025?

If you are interested in decision-making or risk-taking in the real world, I highly recommend this book.

If you are interested in decision-making or risk-taking in the real world, I highly recommend this book. 

The Black Swan by Nassim Nicholas Taleb is one of those books that changed how I view the world 👀 

It describes how much of the world around us is driven by low-probability, high-impact events called Black Swans.

One of my big takeaways from this book is a strategy for decision-making in Black Swan environments called the Barbell Strategy 🏋️

This is essentially an 80-20 approach to resource allocation, where 80% of the resources are put toward a “very safe bet” while the remaining 20% are put toward a “very risky bet”.

Here are a few examples 👇 

- 80% of portfolio in T-bills, 20% in stocks 
- 80% of income comes from salary, 20% from side-hustle 
- 80% of time is spent using skills, 20% of time is spent learning new ones 

What are some other places one could use this 80-20 strategy? 🤔

Conflict is a good thing.

Conflict is a good thing.

… Let me explain.

In the book 📕 The Five Dysfunctions of a Team, Patrick Lencioni says that ”teamwork is the ultimate competitive advantage.”

However, there is one thing that kills teams and their effectiveness.

No.. not conflict, but the FEAR of conflict.

The fear of conflict is widespread. A tell-tale sign of this fear is what Lencioni calls “Artificial Harmony.”

This is when everything looks fine (superficially) but truly isn’t.

There are no arguments, no drama, or no yelling. However, there are hidden conflicts. Things that bother people but no one brings up. 

This is like storing barrels of gasoline in the basement 🛢️🛢️🛢️

All it takes is one spark to blow the whole thing up 💥💥💥

Naturally, you might wonder 🤔 “how can I avoid these hidden conflicts?”

And this brings me to the solution.. conflict itself.

The thing is, the key problem we are facing here is fear 😨

And the way you get over any fear is through exposure 💪

👉Teams that haven’t gone through conflict are much more afraid of conflict.

Thus, these are the teams that suffer the most from “Artificial Harmony” and the FEAR of conflict.

And that’s why conflict is a good thing.

It makes your team more resilient and more effective. 💪💪💪

—

What are some other team killers that you’ve seen?

What’s the “shape” of the S&P 500? 🤔

What’s the “shape” of the S&P 500? 🤔

The S&P 500 is an index capturing the performance of 500 of the largest US companies 📈

Translating these 500 signals into a single index is what we call dimensionality reduction in the data science business. 

While we could use tools like PCA or autoencoders to summarize this information…

… an alternative and more visual approach is to use the Mapper Algorithm 💻

The Mapper Algorithm is a technique under the umbrella of Topological Data Analysis (TDA) that translates data into an interactive network.

This technique is well suited for exploratory data analysis and visualizing high-dimensional data 🧑‍💻

What this looks like when applied to S&P 500 stock tickers is shown in the screenshot below👇

Each node represents a cluster of tickers, where clusters with shared members are connected by an edge.

With this interactive view, we get a whole new modality for exploring and analyzing data 🗺️🔍

6 things I've learned from 6 years in AI...

6 things I've learned from 6 years in AI...


1) Data >

If your model feels fragile, you probably need more data. 

2) Quality > Quantity

However, more data doesn't necessarily imply better performance. It needs to maintain high quality.

3) Experimentation is central

As models get bigger and more powerful, our causal understanding of their mechanisms gets fuzzier. 

This is why experimenting with several potential solution design choices (i.e., data, features, techniques, hyperparameters, etc.) is critical.

4) Continuous learning is mandatory

AI is rapidly evolving. If you are not learning something new every week, you are falling behind.

5) Focus on problems, not tech

Although new techniques and tools are fun to play with, this isn't what generates value. That comes from solving problems.

Don't just ask, "Can I build it?" Also, ask, "Should I build it?

6) Build evals from the start

There is a gap between the technical metrics of a model's performance and business ones. 

Builders need to consider this before writing a single line of code and (ideally) integrate it into the v0 of their system.

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a widely-used data science technique

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a widely-used data science technique

.. but how does it work under the hood? 🤔

PCA creates new variables by combining the original variables to maximize variance.

While this may sound like a hard problem, after a little algebra and calculus, something magically happens 🪄

It turns out that identifying the principal components of a data set is equivalent to solving an Eigenvalue Problem.

👉 Av = λv

This is a standard problem in Linear Algebra and can be solved in a straightforward way.

This was a connection I had come across from time to time, but I didn’t fully understand it until I worked through the math myself.

For the curious, I walk through the algebra step-by-step in an article published in Towards Data Science 

Link in the comments👇

A 5-step framework for finding AI use cases...

A 5-step framework for finding AI use cases...

(that actually generate ROI) 👇 

Every company is trying to use AI right now, but knowing where to start is a challenge, especially if you are new to the technology.

Instead of wasting precious time and resources on random prototypes with little promise of ROI, try this.

Step 1: Ask yourself, what is my organization’s biggest strength? (or weakness?)
Step 2: Write out each step of your existing process for that.
Step 3: Ask yourself, how might we improve these workflows? Generate as many ideas as you can in 5-10 minutes.
Step 4: Plot all your ideas on an "Effort vs Value" chart
Step 5: Pick one of the high-value, low-effort use cases
Repeat.

This will help you both move quickly and focus on applications that (actually) move the needle on business goals.

One of my favorite machine learning techniques is the decision tree 🌲

One of my favorite machine learning techniques is the decision tree 🌲 

They’re intuitive and can be easy to interpret.

However, decision trees notoriously suffer from the overfitting problem ❌ 

This is when an ML model “over-optimizes” to a particular training dataset and has lousy performance on new data. 

A great solution to this problem is a decision tree ensemble 🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲 

This a model that combines the predictions of multiple decision trees instead of merely relying on one. 

🌲 < 🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲 

3 key benefits of decision tree ensembles 👇

👉 No more overfitting (for the most part) 

👉 More robust importance rankings 

👉 Confidence and uncertainty estimates 

I discuss these key benefits more in a recent blog published in Towards Data Science linked below!

Statistics is the bedrock of science and data analysis.

Statistics is the bedrock of science and data analysis. 

However, many of our favorite statistical approaches are useless when dealing with a particular class of data—Power Laws 😮 

In my most recent blog, I give a beginner-friendly guide to Power Laws and lay out 3 problems with using traditional statistical methods to analyze them. 

❌ Problem 1: The Mean is Meaningless—even in large sample it is not representative 

❌ Problem 2: Regression Doesn’t Work—when rare events drive the statistics, prediction is hard (and sometimes impossible) 

❌ Problem 3: Payoffs Diverge from Probabilities—being wrong 1 time can cancel out being right 99 times (and then some).

As someone who is into (both) science and business, I am always finding ways to connect the two (👨‍🔬 + 👨‍💼)

As someone who is into (both) science and business, I am always finding ways to connect the two (👨‍🔬 + 👨‍💼)

One common thread is that they are both concerned with systems. 

Systems consist of rules, behaviors, flows, inputs, outputs, etc. 

If you want to build a great business, you need to be able to build great systems, and who better to learn from than the master system builder—Mother Nature? 🌲🌼☀️🦭

Toward this end, I've come across 7️⃣ lessons from Nature for building great systems.

1) Diversity - monocultures are fragile

2) Redundancy - have 2 lungs in case one fails

3) The waste of one is the fuel of another - e.g. we breathe O2 and exhale CO2, plants do the opposite.

4) Use every nook and cranny of the environment - i.e. niching

5) Adaptation - listen to your environment so that you can respond to it

6) Don't fight entropy, use it.

7) Fractals - designs are self-similar and are generated by simple rules.

👉 What else would you add to the list?

99% of aspiring entrepreneurs don’t do this (to their peril).

99% of aspiring entrepreneurs don’t do this (to their peril).

Here is the one “hack” that I use to move faster than my peers.

💡PAY people 1-2 steps ahead of me to teach me.

Entrepreneurship is hard. Not because of the long hours or constant failure, but because of one’s ignorance.

You are perpetually trying to solve problems you don’t know how to solve (because of a lack of knowledge or skill).

Luckily, there are people who have already solved the problem you are facing.

Unluckily, they are typically busy and don’t have time for a “quick coffee chat”.

The best way shortcut I’ve found for this is to pay people to talk to me.

I recently did this where I paid Daliana Liu to teach me her secrets when it comes to developing a personal brand here on LinkedIn.

Here are my takeaways from the session:

1. Social media is about emotions, not logic
2. The goal isn’t to go viral, it’s to attract your ideal audience
3. Repost and experiment shamelessly (no one cares if you post something twice with tweaks)
4. (Tactical) Links in posts don’t do well… unless you add it in a minute after posting
5. (Tactical) Upload writing examples to Claude and have it describe your style. Then, use that description to have it write post ideas in your likeness.
6. “Steal” formats that are working from bigger creators
7. Invest in a short writing course to learn how to write well

A huge thanks to Daliana for being so generous with her experience and insights 🙏

We all know and love the Fourier Transform ❤️

We all know and love the Fourier Transform ❤️ 

This is when we decompose a signal into a set of simple sines and cosines. 

However, as powerful as the Fourier Transform (FT) is, it suffers one major disadvantage. 

It captures global 🌎 frequency information (i.e. frequencies that persist over an entire signal) 

The downside of this is that the FT doesn’t do a great job of highlighting localized oscillations e.g. a heartbeat 🫀 in ECG. 

We can turn to a different technique for this latter type of signal, the Wavelet Transform. 

The Wavelet Transform decomposes a signal into a set of wavelets. 

Wavelets are like waves, but they are localized in time (i.e. they do not go from -infinity to +infinity) 

This makes it a great tool for analyzing data which sub-signals that persist for short periods.  

-- 

What are other use cases where the Fourier Transform may fall short?
